additionalTextInformation.text:
Looks like 'Master H B with Griffon's Head'
[comment by cda user Paul Jeromack, 28 Jan. 2012]

pageContext.description:
Faith is shown as a woman, who holds an open book in her right hand, while the left hand is raised to instruct. 
[Herrschaft, cda 2015]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 51 x 37 x 1.2 cm (plus 0.5 cm, hidden behind the grooved frame)
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]
pageContext.inscription:
- two lines either side of the head:
'COGNICIONE CHRISTI DON// TA SVNT NOBIS OMNIA/ DIVINE VIRTVTV/ DONTA [?]/ 2. PET[RUS]' 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

metadata.title: Allegory of Faith

pageContext.provenance:
- 1826 Gotha, Art Cabinet, Friedenstein castle, Picture Gallery
- 1856 Ducal Art and Antiquities Collection, Coburg (Herzogliche Kunst- und Altertümersammlung der Veste Coburg (HKA))
- 1919 Kunstsammlungen der Veste Coburg (KVC) 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Support:
- the reverse exhibits toolmarks where the panel has been thinned. At the centre of one plank plane or saw marks are evident perpendicular to the grain. The join between planks III and IV has been covered with a paper strip. The entire reverse was stained a reddish-brown tone.
Paint layers:
- various tiny,  point retouches. The letters of the inscription are not raised, and visible only as glossy areas in the varnish. The insignia is located beneath a thick layer of varnish and had evidently been overlooked during previous intervention. 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

restorationSurveys.remarks:
Conservation treatment  (with a detailed condition report)
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

Conservation treatment (with a detailed treatment report)
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

tests.text:
Identification of wood species: lime wood

[Klein report, 03.03.2016]

- lime wood
- four vertically aligned and butt-joined planks. Widths of the planks on the reverse from the right: plank I: 8.5 cm; plank II: 7.5 cm; plank III: 10.5 cm; plank IV: 10.5 cm
- plank II, probably original thickness, exhibits the characteristic toolmarks of a blockplane
- executed in a fluid medium with a brush, deviates considerably from the final painted version

- probably fixed in the original grooved frame 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110-116]

- remnants of a overpainted inscription. This Latin inscription was inserted either side of the face in capital letters. The lines were scored. The letters were then scratched into the ground and the background was painted black. a binding medium was applied in the depression and gold leaf was then applied. At the right-hand side the preparation for the inscription was not precise enough as the shapes of the letters are unclear. Evidently the scribe could not fit  the text  in the available space. At the right-hand side the text is abbreviated with illegible characters and was uniformly overpainted shortly after. It is not mentioned in the brief description of the paintings in the handwritten inventory of the Picture Gallery, Friedenstein castle in Gotha. It can be reconstructed as follows: 'COGNICIONE CHRISTI DONATA SVNT NOBIS OMNIA DIVINE VIRTUTIS DONA/ 2 PET [RUS]'. It is a free interpretation of the beginning of St Peter's 2nd letter (2 Peter 2-3) [...]

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia at the bottom right: winged serpent with dropped wings and dated '1509'
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]
